title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement IHEID. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/ code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https:// www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing
text: Contributions manystates, whether form issue identification, bug fixes, new code documentation encouraged welcome: Submit issue Document existing code Fix bug implement new features Please note manystates project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

title: Contributing
text: Please use issue tracker GitHub identify problems suggest new functionality, submitting changes code. use issues identify bugs tasks, discuss feature requests, track implementation changes. submitting issue, please provide least ‘Type’ label best describes issue . useful issues ones precisely identify bug, propose test pass instead fails.

title: Contributing
text: Another way contributing package developing vignettes/articles illustrate value added package. Please contact us directly proposals updating documentation, submit issue existing documentation unclear.

title: Contributing
text: Independent assigned code contributions welcome. writing new code, please follow tidyverse style guide based standard R guidelines. can help use packages lintr goodpractice ensure followed. styler package fixes non-invasive way code adhere tidyverse formatting rules, also provides RStudio Addins help task. run lintr goodpractice checks use styler file run: develop new code C++, please follow Google C++ Style Guide.
code: # basic lintr checking lintr::lint_package(path = "manystates/")  # goodpractices checks. Exclude length 80 goodpractice::gp(path = "globalgov/manystates/",    checks = all_checks()[-c(8)])  # styler fix some of the styling issues styler::style_file("filePath")

title: Contributing
text: use two main branches project: origin/master branch reserved fully functional releases model. develop branch reaches stable point, code maintainer merges back master branch, tags release number . origin/develop branch reflects latest model development stage. Contributers encouraged submit minor changes branch enhance existing functionality. New features may break existing functionality committed supporting branches. use two types supporting branches: Feature branches used develop new functionality. exist long feature developed, either merged develop branch incorporation release, deleted feature abandoned. Feature branches branch origin/develop. Hotfix branches used provide fixes severe bugs master branch. way, code maintainer incorporate (potentially unstable) changes develop branch fix issue. Branch names prefixed hotfix-. branching model based : https://nvie.com/posts/-successful-git-branching-model/.

title: Contributing
text: create release version code: Ensure repository --date: git pull. Switch master branch: git checkout master. Merge changes develop branch: git merge ---ff develop. Tag release version: git tag -VX.Y.Z -m "VERSION-NAME". Push changes repository git push origin master --tags.

what: Develop Branch (minor changes to existing functionality)
title: Contributing
text: make minor changes directly develop branch, follow standard git procedures: Make sure switched develop branch project: git checkout -b develop. Make sure local version code --date: git pull origin develop. Make changes Stage changes commit: git add PATH--CHANGED-FILE. Commit changes using appropriate message: git commit -m "DESCRIPTION". Push commit: git push origin develop.

title: Contributing
text: create new feature branch: git checkout -b myfeature develop. merge feature branch back develop:
code: git checkout develop git merge --no-ff myfeature git branch -d myfeature git push origin develop

what: Hotfix Branches (to fix critical bugs in release versions)
title: Contributing
text: create new hotfix branch: git checkout -b hotfix-VERSION master. merge hotfix back master (code maintainer ): develop: Every hotfix increment PATCH digit version number: hotfix branch V1.3.0 named hotfix-V1.3.1, new release tagged V1.3.1. merged master develop, hotfix branch can deleted: git branch -d hotfix-VERSION.
code: git checkout master git merge --no-ff hotfix-VERSION  git tag -a VERSION git push origin develop git checkout develop git merge --no-ff hotfix-VERSION

title: Contributing
text: Commits relate existing issues reference updated status issues, mention issue number (preceded hash symbol: #) commit description: Resolved #31 adding new function things, also updated documentation issue hash (.e. #31) preceded resolve, resolves, resolved, close, closes, closed, fix, fixes, fixed (capitalised ), status issue(s) mentioned updated automatically. current syntactical standard mention issue first provide short description committed changes relation issue. ancillary changes can mentioned comma. written single line, like : #{verb} {issue} {describe main action/changes}, {additional actions/changes}.

title: Contributing
text: use testthat package write unit tests. convention, tests located testthat/tests/. verify tests pass issuing commit existing code. run tests latest version manually: writing new function, consider writing unit test function. follow several conventions writing tests: unit test file test one aspects single function. makes easier identify source bugs, prevents lower-level tests failing higher-level functions change. naming convention test files : test-FILENAME_IN_R_DIRECTORY-FUNCTION_NAME.R, .e. test files named file containing original function R directory, pre-fixed “test”, optionally post-fixed name function tested. test requires auxiliary functions package, e.g. initialize network sample data, belong helper file. one helper file R file, named helper-FILENAME_IN_R_DIRECTORY-FUNCTION_NAME.R. Re-using existing test data preferable creating new data every test.
code: git pull library("testthat") testthat::test_dir("tests/testthat")

title: Contributing
text: Note manystates package version according semantic versioning. means versions follow Major.Minor.Patch semantic format.

what: Step 1: Import the data from {cshapes} and the World Bank
title: Building historical maps with CShapes
text: First, extract data WDI package NY.GDP.PCAP.KD indicator World Bank yields information GDP per capita countries 2010 $. clean data convert ISO country code COW number {cshapes} dataset countrycode package. Second, use {cshapes} package importing world map way consistent many packages universe import_cshapes() function. Finally, perform left_join() dataframes combine mapping data (especially geometry variable contains shapes countries) data GDP 1980. Since historical map, takes information states distances according 1980 (e.g. West East Germany USSR).
code: # Extract GDP from World Bank for the period between 1980 and 1990 library(WDI) library(countrycode) library(dplyr)  GDP <- WDI::WDI(indicator = 'NY.GDP.PCAP.KD', start = 1980, end = 1980) GDP <- dplyr::slice(GDP, 50:266) GDP <- dplyr::as_tibble(GDP) %>%   dplyr::mutate(cowID = as.character(countrycode::countrycode(GDP$iso2c,                                                        origin = "iso2c",                                                        destination = "cowc",                                                        warn = FALSE))) # Import map data with import_cshapes() mapdata <- manystates::import_cshapes(date = "1980-01-01") # Left join on cowNr data <- dplyr::left_join(mapdata, GDP, by = "cowID")

title: Building historical maps with CShapes
text: plot data, leverage {ggplot} geom_sf() layer takes vector polygons input (case geometry variable combined dataframe) create map. also use neat theme hrbrthemes package tweak little prettier output.
code: library(ggplot2) library(hrbrthemes) # for a pretty map  ggplot2::ggplot(data = data$geometry) + # Main plot options   geom_sf(mapping = aes(fill = data$NY.GDP.PCAP.KD), lwd = 0.1) + # Map options   scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma", na.value = "grey80") + # Color options   labs(title = "GDP per capita in 1980",        subtitle = "Some fact about the GDP in 1980.",        caption = "Source: World Bank (retrieved 15/07/2021)",        fill = "GDP per capita") + # Define labels   hrbrthemes::theme_ipsum() + # Set a default theme   theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "light blue"), # Make oceans blue         panel.grid.major = element_blank(),         panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),         panel.border = element_blank()) # Remove grids

what: Have democracies become more free and accountable since the 1990s?
title: Working with manystates data
text: manystates provides data states international system across time, assembling together datasets reputable sources including Correlates War project, Issue Correlates War project, Gleditsch Ward’s dataset interstate system membership. package can also used study related features political regimes (regimes database), contiguity (contiguity database), leadership (leaders database), economic indicators (economics database). illustrate uses data, explore question whether states indeed become free accountable. Since 2017, half states world become democracies. However, time, influential works theorized recent “democratic decay” “stretch”; especially recent(ish) elections leaders authoritarian tendencies several democracies. , use manystates study democratic accountability using data regimes database well import_vdem() function extract Variaties Democracy Data (VDEM) data. regimes database contains data political regimes Polity5 Freedom House datasets.

previous_headings: Have democracies become more free and accountable since the 1990s?
title: Working with manystates data
text: many years, Freedom House data widely relied upon, including media, indicator states democratic. VDEM data developed recently scholars detailed comprehensive understanding democracy. vignette, focus Freedom House VDEM data include electoral, judicial, civil dimensions. Yet, Freedom House VDEM projects also slightly different approaches measurement democracy, explore . Let’s import data first. Due size VDEM data, rely import_vdem() function download data, contrary Freedom House dataset stored internally. Let’s examine first data VDEM selecting variables helpful investigate freedom accountability democracies since 1990s. First, need know state democratic extent. “v2x_regime” variable VDEM differentiates two types democratic regimes (electoral liberal) : Electoral democracy: free fair multiparty elections… Liberal democracy: free fair multiparty elections, access justice, transparent law enforcement, respect personal liberties, rule law… Second, need indicators democracy. Let’s focus transparency accountability (“v2x_accountability_osp”), freedom expression (“v2x_freexp_altinf”), civil society participation (v2x_cspart). variables transformed scales (e.g. 0-1) ordinal data surveys (ordered categorical) follows: Accountability index: low high (0-1) Freedom expression: low high (0-1) Civil society participation: low high (0-1) Freedom House data contains state year data starting year 2012. Therefore, much smaller VDEM. Freedom House also organises data somewhat differently, disaggregating concept democracy two components: political rights (“PR rating” - “” + “B” + “C”) civil liberties (“CL rating” - “D” + “E” + “F” + “G”). FreedomHouseFull dataset also contains raw scores state question, grouped categories labelled alphabets “” “G”. terms indicators democracy, accountability captured category “C”, freedom expression category “D”, civil society participation category “B”. Let’s subset data accordingly.
code: library(manystates) fh <- manystates::regimes$FreedomHouseFull vdem <- import_vdem() library(dplyr) library(tidyr) vdem <- vdem %>% dplyr::select(StateName, stateID, Year,                               v2x_regime, v2x_accountability_osp,                               v2x_freexp_altinf, v2x_cspart) %>%   # select only the variables of interest   dplyr::filter(Year > 1989, v2x_regime == 2 | v2x_regime == 3) %>%   # filter for last 30 years (bigger than 1989) and for democracies only   dplyr::rename(regime = v2x_regime,                 freedom_expression = v2x_freexp_altinf,                 accountability = v2x_accountability_osp,                 civil_society = v2x_cspart) %>% # rename some of these variables   dplyr::mutate(regime_type = case_when(regime == 2 ~ "Electoral Democracy",                                         regime == 3 ~ "Liberal Democracy")) %>%    # create a new regime type variable and rename the categories within   arrange(desc(Year)) %>% # arrange by year   drop_na() # drop rows where there is at least one NA obs... fh <- dplyr::select(fh, c(StateName, stateID, Year, PR, CL, B, C, D)) %>%   # select only the variables of interest   dplyr::filter(PR > 17) %>% # filter for democracies only   manydata::transmutate(freedom_expression = D/16,                         accountability = C/12,                         civil_society = B/16) %>%   # rename and standardise some of these variables   dplyr::mutate(regime_type = ifelse(CL > 52, "Liberal Democracy",                                      "Electoral Democracy")) %>%   # create a new regime type variable and rename the categories within,   # benchmark score derived from Scores table in Freedom House Codebook   arrange(desc(Year)) %>% # arrange by year   drop_na() # drop rows where there is at least one NA obs...

previous_headings: Have democracies become more free and accountable since the 1990s?
title: Working with manystates data
text: Let’s first compare 10 states highest accountability scores (average) dataset since 2012. seems datasets differ somewhat states highest accountability scores (average).
code: library(kableExtra)  vdem_account_10 <- vdem %>% # call data without assigning it   dplyr::filter(Year > 2011) %>% # filter for years in both datasets   group_by(StateName) %>% # group by state name   summarise(Mean_VDEM = mean(accountability)) %>%   arrange(desc(Mean_VDEM)) %>% # arrange the data by mean, in decreasing order   slice(1:10)  fh_account_10 <- fh %>% # call data without assigning it   group_by(StateName) %>% # group by state name   summarise(Mean_FH = mean(accountability)) %>%   # summarize grouped accountability variable by mean   arrange(desc(Mean_FH)) %>%   slice(1:10) # arrange the data by mean, in decreasing order  full_join(vdem_account_10, fh_account_10) %>%    kbl() %>%    kable_styling("striped")

previous_headings: Have democracies become more free and accountable since the 1990s?
what: Pathways: from electoral to liberal democracies (and vice-versa)
title: Working with manystates data
text: Let’s compare states appear multiple democratic regimes since 2012 datasets. VDEM freedom house appear differ quite bit cases transitioned liberal democracies electoral democracies (vice-versa) since 2012. Let’s investigate taking closer look cases appear datasets. Even cases transtions liberal democracies electoral democracies (vice-versa) since 2012 appear datasets, seem somewhat disagree specific years states classified liberal /electoral democracies. Since VDEM state year observations interested democracy pathways since 1990s, let’s work VDEM data now onwards. Let’s just look average differences democracy indicators states multiple regimes.  Although plot informative, appears states averages indicators worse classified liberal democracies comparison electoral democracies. puzzling. Let’s try different approach, plotting averages indicators together time state.  , appears states, aggregated indicators accountability, freedom expression, civil society participation got better moved electoral democracy liberal democracy (e.g. Taiwan), worse moved liberal democracy electoral democracy (e.g. Hungary). cases, clear changed (e.g. Benin) , even puzzling, aggregated indicators got worse moved electoral democracy liberal democracy (e.g. Greece), better moved liberal democracy electoral democracy (e.g. Slovakia).
code: vdem_transition <- vdem %>% # saving this object to use later   dplyr::filter(Year > 2011) %>% # filter for years in both datasets   group_by(StateName, regime_type) %>% # group by state and regime   count() %>% # count grouped observations   group_by(StateName) %>% # re-group by state name only    mutate(Duplicated = n()) %>% # add duplicated columns for state names   filter(Duplicated > 1) %>%  # filter for names that appear more than once   select(-c(Duplicated)) %>% # remove duplicated variables   rename('Years VDEM' = n, 'Regime Type' = regime_type) # rename for clarity  fh_transition <- fh %>% # saving this object to use later   group_by(StateName, regime_type) %>% # group by state and regime   count() %>% # count grouped observations   group_by(StateName) %>% # re-group by state name only    mutate(Duplicated = n()) %>% # add duplicated columns for state names   filter(Duplicated > 1) %>%  # filter for names that appear more than once   select(-c(Duplicated)) %>% # remove duplicated variables   rename('Years FH' = n, 'Regime Type' = regime_type) # rename for clarity  dplyr::full_join(vdem_transition, fh_transition) %>%   arrange(StateName) %>%   kbl() %>%    kable_styling("striped") transition_vdem <- vdem %>% # saving this object to use later   dplyr::filter(Year > 2011) %>% # filter for years in both datasets   group_by(StateName, regime_type) %>% # group by state and regime   summarise(Years_VDEM = paste(Year, collapse = ", ")) %>%   group_by(StateName) %>% # re-group by state name only    mutate(Duplicated = n()) %>% # add duplicated columns for state names   filter(Duplicated > 1) %>%  # filter for names that appear more than once   select(-c(Duplicated)) # remove duplicated variables  transition_fh <- fh %>% # saving this object to use later   group_by(StateName, regime_type) %>% # group by state and regime   summarise(Years_FH = paste(Year, collapse = ", ")) %>%   group_by(StateName) %>% # re-group by state name only    mutate(Duplicated = n()) %>% # add duplicated columns for state names   filter(Duplicated > 1) %>%  # filter for names that appear more than once   select(-c(Duplicated)) # remove duplicated variables  inner_join(transition_vdem, transition_fh) %>%    kbl() %>%   kable_styling("striped") library(ggplot2)  vdem %>%   group_by(StateName, regime_type) %>% # group by state and regime   summarise(Accountability = mean(accountability),             Freedom_of_Expression = mean(freedom_expression),             Civil_Society = mean(civil_society)) %>%   # summarize various grouped variable by mean   group_by(StateName) %>% # re-group by state name only    mutate(Duplicated = n()) %>% # add duplicated columns for state names   filter(Duplicated > 1) %>% # filter for names that appear more than once   pivot_wider(names_from = regime_type,               values_from = Accountability:Civil_Society,               names_sep = "-") %>% # make data wide   mutate(Accountability_dif = `Accountability-Liberal Democracy` -            `Accountability-Electoral Democracy`,          Freedom_of_Expression_dif = `Freedom_of_Expression-Liberal Democracy` -            `Freedom_of_Expression-Electoral Democracy`,          Civil_Society_dif = `Civil_Society-Liberal Democracy` -            `Civil_Society-Electoral Democracy`) %>%    # create variables with mean difference   select(StateName, Accountability_dif, Freedom_of_Expression_dif,          Civil_Society_dif) %>% # select only pertinent observations   pivot_longer(cols = Accountability_dif:Civil_Society_dif) %>%    # pivot table longer again   rename(State = StateName,          Indicator_Difference = name,          Mean_Difference = value) %>% # rename for clarity   ggplot(aes(x = Mean_Difference, y = State,              fill = Indicator_Difference)) + # plot   geom_point(aes(color = Indicator_Difference)) +   facet_wrap("Indicator_Difference") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "none") +   labs(title = "From Electoral to Liberal Democracies",        y = "State",        x = "Mean Difference") vdem %>% # saving this object to use later   group_by(StateName, regime_type) %>% # group by state and regime   count() %>% # count grouped observations   group_by(StateName) %>% # re-group by state name only    mutate(Duplicated = n()) %>% # add duplicated columns for state names   filter(Duplicated > 1) %>%  # filter for names that appear more than once   select(-c(Duplicated)) %>% # remove duplicated variables   select(-n) %>% # remove years   inner_join(vdem, by = c("StateName", "regime_type"), multiple = "all") %>%   # keep only obs in present in both datasets   mutate(Aggregated_Mean_Indicators = (accountability +            freedom_expression + civil_society)/3) %>%   # add rows to form the aggregated indicator   select(StateName, regime_type, Year, Aggregated_Mean_Indicators) %>%   # select only a few variables   rename(State = StateName, Regime = regime_type) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = as.numeric(Year), y = Aggregated_Mean_Indicators,              colour = (Regime == "Liberal Democracy"))) +    geom_line(aes(group=1)) +   facet_wrap("State") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position = "bottom") +   labs(title = "From Electoral to Liberal Democracies (and vice-versa)",        y = "Aggregated Mean Indicators") +   scale_color_discrete(name="Regime",                        labels=c("Electoral Democracy",                                 "Liberal Democracy"))

title: Working with manystates data
text: Perhaps, however, missing important regional information mediates relationship indicators whether states classified liberal electoral democracies. check evolution indicators region? Let’s get join region data HUGGO_STATES database see evolution aggregated indicators per region since 1990s.  Perhaps better question democracies become free accountable since 1990s.
code: HUGGO_STATES <- states$HUGGO_STATES %>%   select(StateName, Region) %>% # select only the variables we want   distinct() # keeps only distinct rolls (no duplicates)  vdem %>%   dplyr::left_join(HUGGO_STATES, by = "StateName") %>%   group_by(Region) %>%   mutate(max_region_year = max(as.numeric(Year)),          min_region_year = min(as.numeric(Year))) %>% # get min and max values for each regions   filter(Year == min_region_year | Year == max_region_year) %>%   # filter for first and last year of data   group_by(Region, Year) %>% # group region and year   summarise(Aggregated_Mean_Indicators = (mean(accountability) +                                             mean(freedom_expression) +                                             mean(civil_society))/3) %>%    # add aggregated means by groups   drop_na() %>%   ggplot(aes(x = Aggregated_Mean_Indicators,       y = reorder(Region, Aggregated_Mean_Indicators),       Fill = Region)) +   geom_point(aes(color = Region)) +   geom_line(aes(color = Region)) +   geom_text(aes(label = Year), nudge_y = 0.3) +   theme_minimal() +   theme(legend.position="none") +   labs(title = "Are democracies better off in 2021 than in 1990?",        subtitle = "Difference aggregated means for indicators of        accountability, freedom of expression, and civil society indicators",        y = "Region",        x = "Mean Difference")

title: Description
text: Please include summary changes issues fixed. Please also include relevant motivation context. List dependencies required change, indicating whether major (breaking), minor, patch change. Please also indicate package changes, data changes, .

title: Description
text: Fixed #(issue .) Closed #(issue .)

title: Description
text: Fixed #(issue .) Closed #(issue .)

title: Description
text: given pull request informative title Description itemizes changes subtitles, e.g. “## Collection”" closed, fixed, related issues referenced explained description , e.g. “Fixed #0 adding ” Package builds OS without issues Package builds Mac Package builds Windows Package builds Linux new modified functions data roxygen style documentation .R scripts longer functions commented inline easier debug future PR description NEWS.md file aligned DESCRIPTION file version bumped appropriate increment (major, minor, patch)

title: contiguity database documentation — contiguity
text: contiguity database list contains following 2 datasets: COW_DIRCONT, HUGGO_CONT. information references datasets used, please use data_source() data_contrast() functions. COW_DIRCONT: dataset 847 observations following 8 variables: dyadID, ContiguityType, Beg, End, stateID1, StateName1, stateID2, StateName2. HUGGO_CONT: dataset 192 observations following 9 variables: stateID, StateName, Beg, End, Contiguity, EntityType, FAOmembership, Group, url.

title: economics database documentation — economics
text: economics database list contains following 2 datasets: EconomicFreedom, EconomicFreedomHist. information references datasets used, please use data_source() data_contrast() functions. EconomicFreedom: dataset 4290 observations following 72 variables: cowID, Year, Countries, Economic Freedom Summary Index, Rank, Quartile, 1A Government Consumption, 1A_data, 1B  Transfers subsidies, 1B_data, 1C  Government investment, 1C_data, 1Di Top marginal income tax rate, 1Di_data, 1Dii Top marginal income payroll tax rate, 1Dii_data, 1D  Top marginal tax rate, IE State Ownership Assets, 1  Size Government, 2A  Judicial independence, 2B  Impartial courts, 2C  Protection property rights, 2D  Military interference rule law politics, 2E Integrity legal system, 2F Legal enforcement contracts, 2G Regulatory restrictions sale real property, 2H Reliability police, Gender Legal Rights Adjustment, 2  Legal System & Property Rights, 3A  Money growth, 3A_data, 3B  Standard deviation inflation, 3B_data, 3C  Inflation: recent year, 3C_data, 3D  Freedom foreign currency bank accounts, 3  Sound Money, 4Ai  Revenue trade taxes (% trade sector), 4Ai_data, 4Aii  Mean tariff rate, 4Aii_data, 4Aiii  Standard deviation tariff rates, 4Aiii_data, 4A  Tariffs, 4Bi  Non-tariff trade barriers, 4Bii  Compliance costs importing exporting, 4B  Regulatory trade barriers, 4C  Black market exchange rates, 4Di  Financial Openness, 4Dii  Capital controls, 4Diii Freedom foreigners visit, 4D  Controls movement capital people, 4  Freedom trade internationally, 5Ai  Ownership banks, 5Aii Private sector credit, 5Aiii  Interest rate controls/negative real interest rates), 5A  Credit market regulations, 5Bi  Hiring regulations minimum wage, 5Bii  Hiring firing regulations, 5Biii  Centralized collective bargaining, 5Biv  Hours Regulations, 5Bv Mandated cost worker dismissal, 5Bvi  Conscription, 5B  Labor market regulations, 5Ci  Administrative requirements, 5Cii  Regulatory Burden, 5Ciii  Starting  business, 5Civ  Impartial Public Administration, 5Cv Licensing restrictions, 5Cvi Tax compliance, 5C  Business regulations, 5  Regulation. EconomicFreedomHist: dataset 458 observations following 5 variables: stateID, Year, StateName, EFW, Rank.

what: Extract CShapes data and matrix — extract_cshapes
title: Extract CShapes data and matrix — extract_cshapes
text: Functions import CShapes 2.0 datasets distances [cShapes] package format consistent many packages universe creating maps.

title: Extract CShapes data and matrix — extract_cshapes
code: import_cshapes(date, ...)  import_distlist(date, type, ...)  import_distmatrix(date, type, ...)

title: Extract CShapes data and matrix — extract_cshapes
text: date date distance list computed. argument must single date (ymd) 1/1/1886 onwards. ... Arguments passed [cshapes] functions. See [cshapes] documentation details type Specifies type distance list: "capdist" capital distances, "centdist" centroid distances, "mindist" minimum distances.

title: Extract CShapes data and matrix — extract_cshapes
text: dataframe [cshapes] dataset format consistent many packages universe. dataframe desired distance list polygons, capitals, polygon centroids kilometers. matrix desired distance list polygons, capitals, polygon centroids kilometers.

title: Extract CShapes data and matrix — extract_cshapes
text: import_cshapes()imports CShapes 2.0 datasets formats consistent many packages universe. import_distlist() imports pre-computed minimum distance dataframe [cShapes] package. Minimum distances computed three ways: distances capitals, distances centroids polygons, minimum distances polygons kilometers. import_distmatrix() imports formats pre-computed minimum distance matrix [cShapes] package. Minimum distances computed three ways: distances capitals, distances centroids polygons, minimum distances polygons kilometers.

title: Extract CShapes data and matrix — extract_cshapes

title: Extract V-Dem and V-Party data — extract_vdem

title: Generate a list of fictional country names — generate_states
code: generate_states(n = 10, prefixed = 0.15, suffixed = 0.15)

title: Generate a list of fictional country names — generate_states
text: n Integer number country names generate library fictional country names. prefixed Proportion country names prefix default 0.15. suffixed Proportion country names suffix default 0.15.

title: Generate a list of fictional country names — generate_states
text: String vector fictional country names

title: Generate a list of fictional country names — generate_states
code: generate_states(12) #>  [1] "Yutria"          "Saint Westenam"  "Boroland"        "Western Telti"   #>  [5] "Cradis"          "Jormos"          "Isle of Karador" "Ugraria"         #>  [9] "Samovar"         "Paradis"         "Toramos"         "Astan"

text: leaders database documentation

code: leaders

title: leaders database documentation — leaders
text: leaders database list contains following 2 datasets: ARCHIGOS, HUGGO_ARCHIGOS. information references datasets used, please use data_source() data_contrast() functions. ARCHIGOS: dataset 17686 observations following 30 variables: archigosID, leaderID, cowID, idacr, StateName, leader, Beg, End, BornDate, DeathDate, YearBorn, YearDied, Female, entry, exit, exitcode, prevtimesinoffice, posttenurefate, dbpedia.uri, num.entry, num.exit, num.exitcode, num.posttenurefate, FtiesNameA, FtiesCodeA, FtiesNameB, FtiesCodeB, FtiesNameC, FtiesCodeC, ftcur. HUGGO_ARCHIGOS: dataset 24 observations following 30 variables: archigosID, cowID, leaderID, idacr, StateName, leader, Beg, End, BornDate, DeathDate, YearBorn, YearDied, Female, entry, exit, exitcode, prevtimesinoffice, posttenurefate, dbpedia.uri, num.entry, num.exit, num.exitcode, num.posttenurefate, FtiesNameA, FtiesCodeA, FtiesNameB, FtiesCodeB, FtiesNameC, FtiesCodeC, ftcur.

title: manystates: States for manydata — manystates-package
text: manystates provide data states international system across time. package combines cross-references several existing datasets consistent manydata package aims.

title: manystates: States for manydata — manystates-package
text: Maintainer: James Hollway james.hollway@graduateinstitute.ch (ORCID) (IHEID) [contributor] contributors: Henrique Sposito (ORCID) (IHEID) [contributor] Bernhard Bieri (ORCID) (IHEID) [contributor] Esther Peev (ORCID) (IHEID) [contributor] Jael Tan (ORCID) (IHEID) [contributor]

title: regimes database documentation — regimes
text: regimes database documentation

title: regimes database documentation — regimes
code: regimes

title: regimes database documentation — regimes
text: regimes database list contains following 4 datasets: Polity5, FreedomHouseStatus, FreedomHouseFull, FreedomHouseAggregate. information references datasets used, please use data_source() data_contrast() functions. Polity5: dataset 17574 observations following 35 variables: ID, stateID, Year, StateName, p5, cyear, ccode, flag, fragment, democ, autoc, polity, polity2, durable, xrreg, xrcomp, xropen, xconst, parreg, parcomp, exrec, exconst, polcomp, prior, eprec, interim, bprec, post, change, d5, sf, regtrans, Beg, End, speccat. FreedomHouseStatus: dataset 11088 observations following 8 variables: ID, stateID, Year, StateName, PR rating, CL rating, Status, Territory. FreedomHouseFull: dataset 1885 observations following 47 variables: ID, stateID, Year, StateName, Region, Edition, Status, PR rating, CL rating, A1, A2, A3, , B1, B2, B3, B4, B, C1, C2, C3, C, Add Q, Add , PR, D1, D2, D3, D4, D, E1, E2, E3, E, F1, F2, F3, F4, F, G1, G2, G3, G4, G, CL, Total, Territory. FreedomHouseAggregate: dataset 3960 observations following 22 variables: ID, stateID, Year, StateName, Region, Edition, Status, PR rating, CL rating, , B, C, Add Q, Add , PR, D, E, F, G, CL, Total, Territory.

title: states database documentation — states
text: states database documentation

title: states database documentation — states
code: states

title: states database documentation — states
text: states database list contains following 7 datasets: GW, ISD, COW, ICOW, ICOW_COL, RATRULES, HUGGO_STATES. information references datasets used, please use data_source() data_contrast() functions. GW: dataset 216 observations following 5 variables: cowID, Beg, End, cowNR, StateName. ISD: dataset 362 observations following 7 variables: cowID, Beg, End, cowNR, StateName, Micro, NewState. COW: dataset 243 observations following 5 variables: cowID, Beg, End, cowNR, StateName. ICOW: dataset 217 observations following 15 variables: cowID, StateName, ColRuler, IndFrom, IndDate, IndViol, IndType, SecFrom, SecDate, SecViol, , IntoDate, COWsys, GWsys, Notes. ICOW_COL: dataset 221 observations following 9 variables: cowID, cowNR, StateName, Beg, cowID_Origin, IndepType, Beg_COW, Beg_GW, Beg_Polity2. RATRULES: dataset 177 observations following 3 variables: stateID, StateName, RatProcedure. HUGGO_STATES: dataset 574 observations following 12 variables: stateID, StateName, Capital, Beg, End, Latitude, Longitude, Area, Region, RatProcedure, Constitutional Description, Source.
